issue.title: RFC: GraphQL Support
issue.body:
Hi! Thanks for the awesome functionality provided by Flat Data!

I have come across the need to make a GraphQL query with Flat Data. Specifically, to gather a set of sponsors for a given GitHub organization. I want to then be able to fetch that data in a static website to show a dynamic list of sponsors. I also believe that there could be many other uses for GraphQL queries that are a natural fit for Flat Data.

I am willing to implement a Pull Request to address this functionality. Before I started implementing this change and level of effort I wanted to ensure the maintainers are open to incorporating the feature.

Any feedback is greatly appreciated! Thanks!

comment.body: This is awesome! Thanks so much for implementing this functionality.

issue.title: RFC: GraphQL Support
issue.body:
Hi! Thanks for the awesome functionality provided by Flat Data!

I have come across the need to make a GraphQL query with Flat Data. Specifically, to gather a set of sponsors for a given GitHub organization. I want to then be able to fetch that data in a static website to show a dynamic list of sponsors. I also believe that there could be many other uses for GraphQL queries that are a natural fit for Flat Data.

I am willing to implement a Pull Request to address this functionality. Before I started implementing this change and level of effort I wanted to ensure the maintainers are open to incorporating the feature.

Any feedback is greatly appreciated! Thanks!

comment.body:
Hi, thanks for the response!

At first glance my thought was to make a new back-end. It seems like a different enough use case that I wouldn't want to potentially impact already existing uses of the HTTP back-end. I also believe it might be easier to configure GraphQL concerns with a specific UI, though that is just a hunch. However, I do not have a strong opinion on this and if you believe a shared back-end is better I could rethink my approach.

I believe that the final end-user solution, particularly the VS Code extension, should be very similar to the HTTP process with the addition of a field/textarea for inputting the body of the GraphQL request.

issue.title: Allow hooks to define their execution order
issue.body: Right now it is not possible to guarantee that multiple hooks of the same type on the same class will execute in a deterministic order. This could prove problematic if multiple hooks are defined that need to be ran in a specific order. We should allow an order to be set for each hook type.

issue.title: Allow easier defining which TestSuite a TestCase belongs to
issue.body:
Right now there are only 2 ways to specify that a TestCase belongs to a TestSuite; you must specify that a TestSuite is the default or you must explicitly specify which TestSuite each TestCase belongs to. An Attribute and a configuration value should be introduced that allows defining a namespace or filepath for a TestSuite class. Any TestCase that falls under that namespace or filepath should be attached to that TestSuite.

Something to consider is the potential for conflicts where a namespace or filepath could result in multiple TestSuites to be associated with. We should likely throw an exception if a scenario like this is encountered.

commits.message: Allow defining test suite for all test cases matching a namespace (#104)

issue.title: Allow integrating a variety of mocking libraries
issue.body: Although we do not provide our own mocking library it is expected that a complex test suite will require mocks at some point. We should design a system that allows you to define which mocking system to use and an abstraction layer will know how to integrate that system into the framework. A more complete design Proposal should be created.

issue.title: Differentiate between a test failure and test error
issue.body: A test is considered not-passing in one of two ways in our current system; the test failed or the test was disabled. Failure occurs if _any_ exception is thrown during the test. This is not an accurate representation of what has actually occurred within the test. A _failure_ should be when an assertion has occurred or the test explicitly throws a `TestFailedException`. An exception that is not expected or was thrown in error should not be considered a failure. It should be considered an _error_ and should throw a `TestErrorException`. The CLI result printer should differentiate between a test failing and a test encountering an unexpected error. The difference between these 2 types of exceptions is important enough to ensure the end-user receives this information.
